review.title: Mary Astell's words in A Serious Proposal to the Ladies (part I), a lexicographic inquiry with NooJ
review.abstract: In the following article we elected to study with NooJ the lexis of a 17 th century text, Mary Astell's seminal essay, A Serious Proposal to the Ladies, part I, published in 1694. We first focused on the semantics to see how Astell builds her vindication of the female sex, which words she uses to sensitise women to their alienated condition and promote their education. Then we studied the morphology of the lexemes (which is different from contemporary English) used by the author, thanks to the NooJ tools we have devised for this purpose. NooJ has great functionalities for lexicographic work. Its commands and graphs prove to be most efficient in the spotting of archaic words or variants in spelling. Introduction In our previous articles, we have studied the singularities of 17 th century English within the framework of a diachronic analysis thanks to syntactical and morphological graphs and thanks to the dictionaries we have compiled from a corpus that may be expanded overtime. Our early work was based on a limited corpus of English travel literature to Greece in the 17 th century. This article deals with a late seventeenth century text written by a woman philosopher and essayist, Mary Astell (1666--1731), considered as one of the first English feminists. Astell wrote her essay at a time in English history when women were "the weaker vessel" and their main business in life was to charm and please men by their looks and submissiveness. In this essay we will see how NooJ can help us analyse Astell's rhetoric (what point of view does she adopt, does she speak in her own name, in the name of all women, what is her representation of men and women and their relationships in the text, what are the goals of education?). Then we will turn our attention to the morphology of words in the text and use NooJ commands and graphs to carry out a lexicographic inquiry into Astell's lexemes.

metadata.title: Mary Astell’s words in A Serious Proposal to the Ladies (part I), a lexicographic inquiry with NooJ

sections.text: Mary Astell's words in A Serious Proposal to the Ladies (Part I), a lexicographic study with NooJélène Pignot SAMM, University of Panthéon-SorbonneParis, France.Odile Piton SAMM, University of Panthéon-SorbonneParis, France. Abstract In the following article, we chose to study with NooJ the lesson of a seventeenth century text, Mary Astell's groundbreaking essay, A Serious Proposal to the Ladies, Part I, published in 1694. We first focused on semantics to see how Astell builds her justification of the female sex she uses to sensitize women to their estranged state and promote their education. Then, we studied the morphology of the lexems we use in contemporary English, thanks to the NooJ tools we have developed for this purpose.

sections.heading: I. About the Author and Remarks on the Text
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 1. 1. Who was Mary Astell?
sections.text: In A Serious Proposal to the Ladies, Part I, first published anonymously in 1694, Mary Astell makes a rather strange suggestion (for the time!): women should withdraw from the world to a "most blessed dwelling," which she even dares to call a monastery (in a country where all monasteries had been closed), where they could enjoy each other's company, spend their time studying, doing good works, and praying (not forgetting their daily church attendance), and this place could also be a refuge for heirs and unmarried women forced to flee the assistants of adventurers and fortune seekers. Her book was widely discussed in her time and satirized by the moralist Richard Steele in the Tatler in 1709, describing Astell as the leader of a "Order of Platonic Ladies" who insisted on celibacy and "was determined to join her Fortune and build a nun."

sections.heading: 1. 2. From the Text to the Digital Text
sections.text: Since the OCR software could not be used for this text, we had to type the text while retaining the original spelling and punctuation. NooJ does not retain the italics, thus losing the literary effects created by Astel's use of italics. In 17th century printing, most nouns are capitalized; the last word (or its last syllable) on the page is repeated at the top of the next page: here "ous" and "home" in Figure 1. Figure 1: frontispiece and excerpt from A serious suggestion to the ladies

sections.heading: 1.3. Astell’s point of view
sections.text: We first focused on semantics to examine how Astell constructs her justification of the female gender, what words she uses to sensitize women to their estranged situation and promote their education. As the object of this study is a literary text, it is initially interesting to study the viewpoint that can be examined by focusing on the use of personal pronouns and possessive adjectives in Astell's text.

sections.heading: 1.3.1. Personal pronouns.
sections.text: The study of personal pronouns highlights various aspects of Astell's rhetoric: she exhorts with the personal pronoun "you," denounces with "you," creates complicity with us, and rarely uses the first person. "The hoard-like aspect of the text can be emphasized when we pick out the sentences in which the pronoun" you "is used (locate the pattern):" How can you be content to be in the world like tulips in a garden, to make a beautiful appearance and be good for nothing? "This functionality enabled us to use expressions like" I pray to you, "I pray to you," "do," "convince you," "everything you need," "everything you need." The text is a prototype, an invitation to women to change their lives and shake off the yoke of ignorance and superficiality.

sections.heading: 1.3.2. References to both sexes in the text
sections.text: In fact, we seek confrontation with people who feel able to surpass themselves.

sections.heading: 1.3.3. Astell’s favourite words: the goals of women's education
sections.text: In Astel's text (apart from grammatical words, which have no meaning here), the most commonly used lexemes are GOD (capitalizes most of the time) and the world. sections.heading: II. Morphological study of Astell's words with NooJ
sections.text: After studying the word length, we record the morphological changes observed and described with NooJ. Some lexemes are modified by a punctuation mark such as an apostrophe (marking omission or contraction) or a hyphen. Other modifications include deviations in attachments. Figure 2: Morphological chart for localizing long words.

sections.heading: 2.1 Long words in Astell's text.
sections.text: In English, long words (as opposed to short Saxon words) are often derived from Latin or Greek. A large number of Latin and Greek words were imported into the English language during the Renaissance. Astell's text is a literary work, and we wondered if we could find the percentage of long words in her text thanks to NooJ. To do this, we created a graph that allows NooJ to locate them. We determined their number and occurrence of each lexicon in a very simple way. The following graph can highlight the words in the text according to their length. To then search for the occurrence of an N-letter word, we use the command < LETTERS + NUMBER >. Our results are presented in Table 3: The total number of long words is 3659 out of 18,759 words in the text, i.e. a percentage of about 19.5%. This graph allows us to determine the percentage of long words and to find very long words (e.g. 16: uncharitability and some double words).

sections.heading: 2.2. Study of compounds and juxtaposed words
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.2.1 Hyphenated compounds
sections.text: In order to recognize these forms, we have used the following syntactic graph: This graph highlights a systematic tendency to isolate the 17th century spelling prefix from the root using hyphenation (first path). Figure 3: Syntactic graph for compoundsThis resulted in 28 results or occurrences of the NooJ-approved formula1-wort2 (for example, god-like for god-like or prefix for preengage). During the search, NooJ also relies on another graph that allows it to take into account the conversion of the prefix -in -en or -en into -in (as we saw in a related article, Piton and Pignot, 2008). Sometimes, a merging of two separate words also needs to be performed, such as in "where-J" always this conversion is made by our request to "Noostein."

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Juxtaposed words
sections.text: Some words result from the concatenation or merging of two lexemes, as in the case of personal pronouns (myself for myself). In 17th century English, these words were spelled as adjacent words instead of a single entity. We came across a few occurrences of this type of word in Astell's text; the second way in Figure 3 allows us to systematically search for them. Besides personal pronouns such as "her self," "our self" (whose spelling suggests that "self" was perceived as a noun), we found 11 connections: any body, every day, forever, each, each, each thing, often, as wisely, to this day, no body, backward. However, this connection also produces a lot of noise and comical results: are one, area; be one, a bean; direct or, director; not able to be remarkable; and yet I, yeti! Some connections in contemporary English are still generated by hyphens, while verb (except when the prefix and adjective do not end with the first).

sections.heading: 2.3 Words with apostrophes
sections.text: There are more apostrophe than full points (356) and three times fewer than commas (1334). In 17th-century typography, many words could be written with an apostrophe indicating the omission of a letter, usually the mute e. In addition to 118 previous participle in "d or" t, some "s and some familiar contradictions, we have extracted other contracts not included in the NooJ dictionary because they are not used in contemporary English. These contradictions had to be adequately described and added to our dictionary. Here are a few examples: e'er, < it, ADV > + UNAMB and" twou'd, < it, it, PRO + 3 + n + s > < would, V + PT + s > + UNAMB. sections.heading: 2.4.1 Inflectional affixes for adjectives, adverbs and verbs
sections.text: In 17th-century English, any adverb or adjective, regardless of its length, can form the comparative by adding the addition of -er and the superlative by adding -est. The following graph can locate superlatives and comparatives; in Astell's text, it can locate the archaic form word (a double comparative bad expression). Figure 4: Recognition of the comparative and the superlative Astell only uses the comparative in -er and the superlative in -est for short words. Among the grammatical appendages typical of 17th-century English, the verb inflections in -est and -th (st, 2nd-person singular, -th or -st singular) should be mentioned in the present and in the preterit. They can be discovered thanks to the following graph and are recognized as valid verb forms when s or it is added to the root. Our early work was based on a limited corpus of English travel literature to Greece in the 17 century. Astell wrote her essay at a time in English history when women were “the weaker vessel” and their main business in life was to charm and please men by their looks and submissiveness. In this essay we will see how NooJ can help us analyse Astell's rhetoric (what point of view does she adopt, does she speak in her own name, in the name of all women, what is her representation of men and women and their relationships in the text, what are the goals of education?). Then we will turn our attention to the morphology of words in the text and use NooJ commands and graphs to carry out a lexicographic inquiry into Astell's lexemes. I. About the Author and Remarks on the Text 1. 1. Who was Mary Astell? In A Serious Proposal to the Ladies, part I, first published anonymously in 1694, Mary Astell makes a rather odd suggestion (for the period!): women should withdraw from the world in a “blest abode” that she even dares to call a convent (in a country where all convents had been closed down). There they might enjoy each other’s company, spend their time in study, good works and prayer (without forgetting daily church attendance). This place could also be a refuge for heiresses and unmarried women who need to escape the assiduities of adventurers and fortune seekers. Her book was widely discussed in her day and satirised by the moralist Richard Steele in the Tatler in 1709, calling Astell the leader of “an order of Platonick Ladies” bent on celibacy and “resolv'd to join their Fortunes and erect a Nunnery” in Steele (1709). According to the historian Antonia Fraser (1984, 404), what inspired Astell to write her proposal was the life of her friend Hortense Mancini, Duchesse de Mazarin, King Charles II’s ex-mistress, who was the subject of numerous scandals, such as “the running away in Disguise with a Spruce Cavalier”! Astell was convinced her friend’s “unhappy shipwreck” pointed out “the dangers of an ill Education and unequal marriage” (1700, 3). A Serious Proposal to the Ladies, part I, is signed “by a Lover of her Sex” and was first published anonymously in 1694 when the author was only 28. Part II (which will not be tackled here) is an application of Descartes’ and Malebranche’s philosophy to the education of women. 1. 2. From the Text to the Digital Text OCR software could not be used for this text so we had to type the text preserving the original spelling and punctuation. NooJ does not keep the italics, hence the literary effects created by Astell’s use of italics are lost. In 17 century printing, most nouns are capitalised. The last word (or its last syllable) on the page is repeated at the top of the next page: here “ous” and “home” in illustration 1. Illustration 1: Frontispiece and Excerpt from A Serious Proposal to the Ladies 1.3. Astell’s point of view We first focused on the semantics, to examine how Astell builds her vindication of the female sex, which words she uses to sensitise women to their alienated condition and promote their education. As the object of this study is a literary text, it is interesting first to study point of view, which can be examined by focusing on the use of personal pronouns and possessive adjectives in Astell’s text. 1.3.1. Personal pronouns. The study of personal pronouns highlight different aspects of Astell’s rhetoric: she exhorts with the personal pronoun “you”, denounces with “they”, creates complicity with we, and seldom uses the first person “I”. The hortatory aspect of the text may be highlighted when we extract the sentences in which the pronoun “you” is used (locate pattern you): “How can you be content to be in the World like Tulips in a Garden, to make a fine shew and be good for nothing; have all your Glories set in the grave...” This functionality enabled us to extract expressions such as “I pray you”, “I entreat you”, “render you”, “persuade you”, I “would have you”, “all that is required of you”. The text is a protrepsis, an exhortation to women to change their lives and shake off the yoke of ignorance and superficiality. The frequent use of the pronoun “we” is meant to encourage identification with the author and with a community of women sharing the same fate in a male-dominated society. By contrast, the occurrences of “I, me, my” account for 4.56 % of pronouns. Astell does not use the pronouns “I” and “me” very much: these self-references (84) account for only 0.44% of the words of the text, which points to her self-effacement as an author, to be linked with that of the female author in the 17 century. Incidentally, it should be noted that her book is signed “by a Lover of her Sex”, and not under her own name. In her preface to Letters Concerning the Love of God (1695,4), Astell says she wants “to slide gently through the world without so much as being seen or taken notice of.” Personal pronouns occurrences Total by group Me/ my self / my / I 12 / 5 / 15 / 52 84 Thou / Thy / thine 0 0 She / her 129 / 183 129 He / him / his 18 / 24 / 24 631 We / us / our 141 / 88 / 144 373 You / your 125 / 81 206 They / them / their 148 / 111 / 159 418
